articles.headline: For BP, Toll Likely to Extend Past Cleanup
articles.snippet: Although BP  generates billions of dollars in profit every quarter, the oil spill is rattling government and investor confidence.
articles.abstract: Although BP  generates billions of dollars in profit every quarter, the oil spill is rattling government and investor confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the face of it, BP can easily afford to pay the short-term costs of the oil well that is leaking millions of gallons into the Gulf of Mexico. Last year, the company earned $17 billion, and it ended the year with more than $8 billion in cash.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Aiming at Rivals, Starbucks Will Offer Free Wi-Fi
articles.snippet: Starting July 1, Starbucks locations in the United States will offer wireless service via AT&T, and digital content will be offered through a partnership with Yahoo.
articles.abstract: Starting July 1, Starbucks locations in the United States will offer wireless service via AT&T, and digital content will be offered through a partnership with Yahoo.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many coffee shops try to discourage people from buying a cup of coffee and then lingering for hours to use the free Internet access. Starbucks will soon encourage them to stay as long as they want.

articles.headline: Awaiting the Genome Payoff
articles.snippet: The Human Genome Project has not produced the promised cornucopia of new drugs.
articles.abstract: The Human Genome Project has not produced the promised cornucopia of new drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH WALES, Pa.  At Merck’s “automated biotechnology facility” here, robot arms adapted from automobile factories deftly shuttle plates containing human cells.

articles.headline: Giving In on Trading, Bankers Turn to Other Losses
articles.snippet: With the so-called Volcker Rule likely to become law, banks are battling hard to fend off more restrictions.
articles.abstract: With the so-called Volcker Rule likely to become law, banks are battling hard to fend off more restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Bankers have all but given up on defeating one of the most contentious provisions in the financial regulation bill  one that would effectively bar federally insured banks from trading for their own accounts  and are now focusing on battles like heading off a prohibition on derivatives trading.

articles.headline: Setbacks Cloud U.S. Plans to Get Out of Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Halting progress has crystallized tensions over President Obama’s plan to begin pulling out troops by July 2011.
articles.abstract: Halting progress has crystallized tensions over President Obama’s plan to begin pulling out troops by July 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Six months after President Obama decided to send more forces to Afghanistan, the halting progress in the war has crystallized longstanding tensions within the government over the viability of his plan to turn around the country and begin pulling out by July 2011.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Mark Landler

articles.headline: One Crowd Still Loyal to Goldman Sachs
articles.snippet: Despite the talk of fraud, a big settlement and even criminal charges, most of Goldman’s big customers are not bolting.
articles.abstract: Despite the talk of fraud, a big settlement and even criminal charges, most of Goldman’s big customers are not bolting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lots of people are talking about what is happening at Goldman Sachs. This is a column about what is not happening at Goldman.

articles.headline: Plea to Buy Is Hard Sell in Germany
articles.snippet: Trading partners want Germans to go on a shopping spree, increase imports and help countries like Greece and Spain grow faster so they can pay off their debts.
articles.abstract: Trading partners want Germans to go on a shopping spree, increase imports and help countries like Greece and Spain grow faster so they can pay off their debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  Germany’s trading partners want the country to go on a shopping spree, increase imports and help countries like Greece and Spain grow faster so they can pay off their debts. But a look at recent history suggests that it might be a bad idea to rely on German consumers for a European recovery.

articles.headline: Cameron Calls N. Ireland Killings ‘Unjustified’
articles.snippet: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain apologized as a report on the “Bloody Sunday” shootings was released.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain apologized as a report on the “Bloody Sunday” shootings was released.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron offered an extraordinary apology on Tuesday for the 1972 killings of 14 unarmed demonstrators by British soldiers in Northern Ireland, saying that a long-awaited judicial inquiry had left no doubt that the “Bloody Sunday” shootings were “both unjustified and unjustifiable.”
